## Overview

This is a basic template using `CSS` for paged media. 
The output file is a `PDF`. 
You can customize it using `CSS` rules.  

## Some examples of customization

Providing a `CSS` tutorial is under the scope of `weasydoc`. To learn how to 
use CSS with `rmarkdown`, it is recommended to read _R Markdown: The Definitive Guide_([bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown](https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/)).   
However, you will find here some demos of `CSS` customizations using pandoc's 
`markdown`.

### Add styling rules to divs and spans

You can modify a portion of the text using 
[bracketed spans](https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#extension-bracketed_spans):  

```markdown
The following bracketed text [will be rendered **in red**]{style="color: red;"}.
```

The following bracketed text [will be rendered **in red**]{style="color: red;"}.

If you want to style a block of content, you can use [fenced divs](https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#extension-fenced_divs):

```markdown
:::{style="text-transform: uppercase;"}  
Make this paragraph uppercase.  

And this one, too.  
:::  
```

:::{style="text-transform: uppercase;"}  
Make this paragraph uppercase.  

And this one, too.  
:::  

### Put the styling rules in CSS declarations

The use of `style` declaration is discouraged. Defining CSS classes is a best 
practice.  
Thanks to the [`css` `knitr` engine](https://bookdown.org/yihui/rmarkdown/language-engines.html#javascript-and-css), you can insert CSS declarations in your `Rmd` file.

You can define rules applied to custom classes...

~~~css
`r ''````{css, echo=FALSE}
.rotated {  
    transform: rotate(-45deg);
}
.bg-lightsteelblue {  
    background-color: LightSteelBlue;
}
.box2 {  
    height: 20mm;
    width: 20mm;
    margin: auto;
}
.box2 > p {  
    line-height: 20mm;
    text-align: center;
}
`r ''````
~~~

```{css, echo=FALSE}
.rotated {
  transform: rotate(-45deg);
}
.bg-lightsteelblue {
  background-color: LightSteelBlue;
}
.box2 {
  height: 20mm;
  width: 20mm;
  margin: auto;
}
.box2 > p {
  line-height: 20mm;
  text-align: center;
}
```

... and reuse them in your RMarkdown document.

```markdown
:::{.box2 .bg-lightsteelblue .rotated}
Hello! 
:::
```

:::{.box2 .bg-lightsteelblue .rotated}
Hello! 
:::



## Top level variables

### Compulsory variable: `lang`

There is only one compulsory variable: `lang` that defines the language of the document.  
See the [language variables section](http://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#language-variables) of the `pandoc` documentation.

### Papersize

The `papersize` variable control the size of the pages. You can use:

- a well-known size: `a4`, `letter`... 
You can add `landscape` for orientation, for instance: `"a5 landscape"`.
- a customized size: `"4in 6in"`...

### Margins

There is no `geometry` option. In order to control the margins, you have to use `margin-top`, `margin-right`, `margin-bottom` and `margin-left` variables.

### Font size

The `fontsize` variable control the main size of the font for the document. Its default value is `11pt`.

### Line spacing

The line spacing is controlled by the `lineheight` variable. It replaces the `linestretch` variable of `pdf_document`.  
The default value is 1.4. If you want double line spacing, you can set the `lineheight` value to 2.

### Using a `sans-serif` main font

The defaut main font is a `serif` font. If you prefer a `sans-serif` font, you can add the `main-sans-serif: true` option to the `YAML` header.

### Specify `mainfont`

With `mainfont`, you can change the main font for the document.

### Specify `monofont`

You can change `monofont`.

### Font titles

Use `titlefont` or `title-serif`.

### monofontsize

### Text alignment

The text is justified by default. You can modify this behavior with the `textalign` variable. See values in CSS specifications.

### Page counter

You can add page counter with the `pagecounter` variable

### Number sections

Use `number-sections`.

## Built-in classes

The `weasydoc::wpdf_document` provides a set of built-in classes. They can be overridden with a customized `CSS` style.

### Paper orientation

You can add the class `portrait` or `landscape` to change the orientation.

For instance, the following `data.frame` will be print in landscape mode.

    `r ''````{r echo=FALSE, class.output="landscape"}
    mtcars
    ```

```{r echo=FALSE, class.output="landscape"}
mtcars
```
